div.p: ROSE and COLIN, A COMIC OPERA, IN ONE ACT. As it is performed at the THEATRE-ROYAL IN COVENT GARDEN.
LONDON: Printed for G. KEARSLY, No. 46, Fleet-Street. M. DCC. LXXVIII.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p: THE following little Piece is an imitation of the French comic operas of one act, which are generally characterized, either by their natural ſimplicity, or ſome ſingle ſtriking incident, and little or nothing more is deſigned.—It is now firſt attempted to introduce this ſpecies of entertainment on the Engliſh theatre, as containing excellent ſituations for light airs.—On the French ſtage, notwithſtanding all their merit, they tire in the length of time taken for repreſentation; and, were they ſpun out to the common length of our afterpieces, it is conceived they would be found ſtill more inſufficient.
The ſubject matter therefore being wholly preſerved, and the dialogue both varied and compreſſed, they are, with every deference, ſubmitted to public judgment.

div.head: CHARACTERS.
div.p: SCENE, the inſide of a Cottage.

body.head: ROSE and COLIN, A COMIC OPERA.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: The inſide of a Cottage, on one hand a ſtair-caſe, on the other a window which opens and ſhuts; under the window is a table and arm chair, and very near it are hanging a ſaddle and bridle; on the table are a cuſhion and bobbins for making lace, a ſpinning-wheel and ſeveral ſkiens of flax are lying about; and there is another chair upon which (in the courſe of the piece) Roſe ſets down to work. Roſe is diſcovered.

lg.l: POOR Colin! ah me, how I fear,
Leſt he ſhould raſhly venture here!
I'm quaking like a timid mouſe,
My father runs through all the houſe,
Overturning every chair and table;
The barn, the outhouſe, and the ſtable;
Acroſs the farm-yard, in the ſtreets,
Threatning every thing he meets.
Poor Colin, &c.
What the deuce can be come to him?
If with tears I would ſubdue him;
With anger he directly burns,
And raves and ſcolds, and ſwears by turns;
Crying, ſince Eve, better nor worſe,
Women were born to be a curſe.
Poor Colin, &c.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: I can't think for the life of me what my father would be at, running about ſo:—I muſt get him out ſome how, for if Colin ſhould come, and he ſhould ſee him—

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: What are you ſtanding here with your hands before you like a gentlewoman for?

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Father, I—

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: I—well—why don't you go to work?

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: I left my work, father, to look for—

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: To look for what?

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: A—for your—a—for your hat, father.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: My hat!—what the devil do you want with my hat?—well there then you have found • t, 'tis upon my head.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Becauſe ſeeing you run about ſo, I • hought you wanted it to go out.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: To go out!—what ſhould I go out • or?

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Why you talked of going out to buy • ome corn.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Yes, but my neighbour Higgins's ſon • s gone to buy for us both.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: What, Colin!

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Yes, Colin—what do you ſigh for?

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Nothing,

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: See who's at • he door.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: I can't get him out.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Sighing and whining—A young dog, • e has caught her, I can ſee that plain enough.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: 'Tis farmer Higgins, father.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Farmer, I am glad to ſee thee—go and • raw ſome ale, daughter,

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.p: Well, neighbour Gregory, how doſt?

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Why, neighbour, I ſhould be better if was better pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.p: Ay!—why, what has fallen out to vex •• ee?

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt know—but firſt let me aſk thy advice—we are both widowers, you know your wife has left you a ſon, and mine has left me a daughter.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.p: Roſe and Colin.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: True—but if thy lot had been to have had the daughter inſtead of the ſon, and a young impudent dog had come when thou waſt in the field, or at market, or in the barn—

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.p: What, telling a ſoft tale in her ear, I warrant you—why I'd tell him, ſays I, calling him by his name—ſays I, my child is another gueſs ſort of a child, ſhe is not for thee, thou art a libertine, and if thou com'ſt here again, I ſhall be angry, I ſhall bruſh thy jacket.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Well ſaid, neighbour Higgins—now hear what I have got to ſay—laſt night I had been late cocking the hay, and when I come home, being a ſort of owl light, I could juſt ſee ſome thing crawl upon all fours towards the door, ſo taking it ſor a dog I gave it a good kick—upon this my daughter runs up to me with—dear father, I'm glad you're come home, I'm glad to ſee you, I'm glad no miſchief has happened to her, I'm glad,

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.p: So, ſo.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: And all this thou ſee'ſt that I might not find out what ſort of a four-legged animal it was—but I'cod I was too cunning for her—looking out of the window, I found Mr. Dog to be no other than Maſter Colin, your ſon.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.p: Ah, ah!—This is the reaſon he is ſighing and flouting about ſo then—I can't get him of late days to mind any kind of work.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Nor can I my daughter.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.p: What ſhall we do?

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Why, truly, I don't know.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.p: Suppoſe we marry them together.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: That's true—but ſuppoſe this ſhould be only a flighty pack of nonſenſe that will laſt but a month.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.p: Try 'em, try 'em, let us try 'em.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.p: Here comes your daughter, ſeem as if we had quarrelled, and forbid me your houſe, then preſently come to me that we may counſel together.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.p: An old doating fool, to pretend that I don't know the price of grain,

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Call that indeed clear wheat, when it has been half eat up by the rats.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Dear me, they ſeem to be quarrelling—here's the ale, father; will you pleaſe to drink, neighbour Higgins?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.p: Not I—I won't taſte a drop of his ale.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Put it down, daughter—put it down—he ſhan't taſte a drop of it, was it ever ſo.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Dear father, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: In one word, get out of my houſe.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.p: I don't want to ſtay in it—and, dy'e mark me? never let you or your's come near mine—an old ſtupid—doating—not know the price of corn indeed!

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Go thy ways, thou old fool—and thou, daughter, if I ever know thee ſpeak to his ſon—I am going out, and if thou ſuffer'ſt that young dog to come lurking about my houſe—ſee'ſt thou this oak ſaplin—he ſhall get it—however for this time the key ſhall anſwer for thee—as I go out I'll double lock the door.

lg.l: With neither dog, nor ſcrip, nor ſtaff,
I rather by half,
A flock of ſheep would guard,
Then a puling wench ſighing up and a-bed,
With love in her head,
Nor would the taſk be half ſo hard.
All council's thrown away and loſt,
Advice is out of ſeaſon,
Nor the devil a bit, no more than a poſt,
Can you get her to hear reaſon;
Whining,
Pining,
Groaning,
Moaning;
It is her way,
Each hour o'th' day;
Tell her why,
She heaves a ſigh;
Tell her to diſcloſe her fears,
Her anſwer is a ſhower of tears.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Yonder he goes—what can be the matter—they were ſuch good friends too—'tis a ſad thing not to be dutiful—but 'tis a ſadder thing not to love Colin.

lg.l: I loſt my poor mother
When only a child;
And I fear'd ſuch another,
So gentle and mild,
Was not to be found.
But I ſaw my miſtake,
For ſcarce was ſhe gone,
But I prov'd I had father and mother in one
And though, at this minute, he makes my heart ach,
There's not ſuch another, ſearch all the world round.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: I'd reach'd my teens fairly,
As blythe as a bee,
His care, late and early,
Being all to pleaſe me.
No one thing above ground
Was too good for his Roſe;
At wake or at fair,
I was dreſs'd out ſo gaily, lord, people would ſtare;
And I ſay it again, though he's peeviſh, God knows,
There's not ſuch another, ſearch all the world round.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: But love, who, they tell us,
Does many ſtrange things,
Makes all the world jealous
And mad—even kings,
They ſay, he can wound.
This love is the ſore
Since Colin came here,
This father, ſo kind, is a father ſevere;
Yet ſtill will I ſay, though he ſcolds more and more,
There's not ſuch another, ſearch all the world round.

div.head: SCENE VII.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Roſe! Roſe!

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Oh dear! 'tis him, and the door is double-locked.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Roſe, open the door—I've watched the old man out—what the miſchief, is not ſhe at home?—let us ſee.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: I can't open it, dear Colin—my father has locked it—come again in the evening; he does not hear me ſure— (looking through the key-hole) dear me, he's gone—Oh! how my heart beats—that I could not ſpeak to him now—he was in a great hurry to go I think—Oh! the wicked rogue, there he is climbing up at the window—I'll hide myſelf, and vex him a little in his turn.
sp.stage: (She hides herſelf under the ſtairs, and Colin opens the window.)

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p:
Roſe!—Roſe!—no, there's nobody at home; well, I'll leave her the poſey I brought, however; (he tries to throw it upon the table, and tumbles it upon the ground) The deuce take it, I have let it fall upon the ground, and ten to one if her father don't trample upon it—if I could but get in now I could put it upon the table—hang it, I can get in well enough— (As he gets in at the window he lets his hat fall
on the outſide) Well done I—my hat's tumbled—never mind—I can pick it up when I go out.
sp.stage: (He gets down, puts the noſegay upon the table, and regards the cuſhion and bobbins with which Roſe has been making lace; and Roſe, now and then, either ſhews herſelf, or gets under the ſtaircaſe, as ſhe finds occaſion, during the following ſong)

lg.l: Here's all her geer, her wheel, her work,
Theſe little bobbins to and fro;
How oft l've ſeen her fingers jirk,
Her pretty fingers white as ſnow!
Each object to me is ſo dear,
My heart at ſight on't throbbing goes;
'Twas here ſhe ſat her down—and here—
She told me ſhe was Colin's Roſe.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: This poſey, for her, when ſhe's dreſs'd,
I've brought, alas! how happy I!
Could I be, like theſe flowers, careſs'd;
And, like them, on her boſom die.
The violet and pink I took,
And every pretty flower that blows;
The roſe too, but how mean 'twill look,
When by the ſide of my ſweet Roſe!

div.stage: (At the end of the ſong Colin begins climbing up to get out at window, which Roſe perceiving, ſhe throws a ſkein of flax at him; when he turns, ſpeaking as he deſcends.)

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Ah you rogue you—what you are there?

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Yes, dear Colin—but don't come down, go away directly.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Nay, but dear Roſe.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: I'll tell thee all at night—pray now go, you frighten me out of my wits; beſides, the window opens into Goody Fidget's garden, and ſhe's a ſcandalous old goſſip.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Never mind her.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: My father is at the door—I hear him.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Odds wounds! I'll get away then—one kiſs.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: No, no—make haſte.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p:
How happened it that
the caſement is got ſo faſt now—here he comes, I muſt e'en ſtay where I am.

div.stage: (He reſts upon the ledge of the window, now and then trying to open the caſement, and leaving off for fear of making a noiſe.)

div.head: SCENE VIII.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Yes, yes, 'tis juſt as I feared; 'tis in every body's mouth—heyday! what's all this—the ſpinning-wheel in one place—the flax in another—nothing but tidling and tidling of that damned lace—'twould be better for you if you'd mind your ſpinning—Ah well, my comfort is, that rogue Colin's far enough off; his father has ſent him away for three years (Roſe ſmiles to herſelf, but as often as her father looks at her ſhe ſeems grave) what, you pout about it—'tis cruel, is it not?—ſhe ſhall have her Colin—Colin—the very name puts me in a paſſion; I'll trim him—I'll—but he's gone—he's gone, that's my comfort (yawning) come take your wheel and go to your work—I have not had my afternoon's nap—I'll try if I can ſleep while you ſing.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Do, father—if you don't take your afternoon's nap I am afraid you'll be ſick

div.stage:
( • he
puts the chair on the oppoſite ſide, and takes her ſpinning-wheel.)

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Come, ſing.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: What ſhall I ſing, father?—that ſong about Colin?

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Always Colin—nothing but Colin—ſing what you've a mind—if I ſleep about an hour wake me, do you hear?

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Yes, father.

lg.l: There was a jolly ſhepherd lad,
And Colin was his name;
And, all unknown to her old dad,
He ſometimes to ſee Peggy came,
The object of his flame.
One day, of his abſence too ſecure,
Her father thunder'd at the door;
When fearing of his frown,
Says ſhe, dear love, the chimney climb;
I can't, cries he, there is not time,
Beſides, I ſhould tumble down.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: What could they do, ta'en unawares?
They thought and thought again;
In cloſets underneath the ſtairs,
To hide himſelf, 'twere all in vain,
He'd ſoon be found, 'twas plain;
Get up the chimn • y, love, you muſt,
Cried ſhe, or elſe the door he'll burſt;
I would not for a crown;
Young Colin ſeeing but this ſhift,
E'en mounted up, Peg lent a lift,
And cry'd don't tumble down.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: With throbbing heart now to the door
Poor Peggy runs in haſte;
Thinking to trick her father ſure,
But haſte, the proverb ſays, makes waſte,
Which proverb here's well-plac'd;
Her father ſcolded her his beſt;
Call'd names, and ſaid, among the reſt,
Pray have you ſeen that clown?
She ſcarce had time to anſwer, no;
When, black all over as a crow,
Young Colin tumbled down.

div.stage: (During the ſong Colin makes ſeveral efforts to open the caſement as ſoftly as poſſible; and, juſt at the end of it, as Roſe repeats the words "tumbled down," for the laſt time, puſhing it very hard, his foot ſlips, and he tumbles down upon the table, carrying with him the bridle and ſaddle which hang in his way; this jolts Gregory almoſt out of his chair, who ſtarts up.)

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Icod, and ſo I have—what the deuce, Roſe, put it in your head to ſing that ſong?

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: What's that!—what the devil's that—Is the houſe tumbling down!—what's the matter!—

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Dear father!—Colin!—

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Who the devil have we got here?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Why, 'tis I.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Oh! 'tis you, you young raſcal, is it!—and where did you come from?—through the roof of the houſe, or down the chimney?

sp.speaker: Roſe
sp.p: You have not hurt yourſelf, Colin, have you?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: No, Roſe—you en't frighten'd, I hope, are you?

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Frighten'd! how the devil ſhould ſhe be otherwiſe, coming into my houſe like a bomb or a cannon-ball—but you can ſet all to rights—don't be frightened, Roſe, 'tis I, your dear Colin—but tell me, once for all, what brought you here?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: I come—I—I—come, neighbour.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: I come—I—I—come—for what?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: To bring you home—

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: That.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: That—what the devil's that?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Why, the ſaddle and bridle you lent father.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Lent father—why, you dog, I never lent your father a ſaddle and bridle.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: I hope you are pretty well, neighbour Gregory, and your daughter Roſe.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Oh! yes, yes, we are mighty well, and now pray get about your buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Lord! farmer Gregory, why are you haſty? it did not uſe to be ſo.

lg.l: Excuſe me, pray ye do, dear neighbour,
But Roſe, you know, and I,
Have oft partook one ſport or labour
While you have pleas'd ſtood by.
And ſince, from little children playing,
You've kindly call'd me ſon,
I thought, to Roſe, I might be ſaying
"Good-day," and no harm done.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: When you and father gravely counted,
One morning, in the barn,
To how much, in a day, it 'mounted
That both of us could earn,
Since then you down the law were laying,
And calling me your ſon,
I thought, to Roſe, I might be ſaying,
"Good day," and no harm done.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Here comes your father—he'll tell you why ſo.

div.head: SCENE laſt.
div.stage: GREGORY, COLIN, HIGGINS, ROSE, GOODY FIDGIT.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.p: So, farmer, Goody Fidgit here has a fine ſtory to tell you.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Ay! why, to what do we owe the ſight of her?

sp.speaker: Goody.
sp.p: Why, you owe the ſight of me to your own goings on—Lord! Lord! that parents, now-a days, have no more prudence—you ought to be aſhamed of yourſelves, two men of your age—Thou, Nicholas Gregory, was born the 7th of January, in the year—

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Well, well, we know how old we are—go on.

sp.speaker: Goody.
sp.p: And you have no more grace than to let that forward minx, your daughter, chatter to that rogue Colin, every night, out of the window.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Dear, dear, how can that be, when I lie in the next room to my father?

sp.speaker: Goody.
sp.p: So you do; and you get up again, and creep down a ladder by the way of the grainery.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Lord! lord!

sp.speaker: Goody.
sp.p: Ah, 'tis no ſecret—all the village knows it.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: I wiſh I could catch any body telling me of it, I'd have a touch at them.

sp.speaker: Goody.
sp.p: Well, I tell thee of it then; now thou may'ſt have a touch at me if thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: 'Tis a great lie, I tell you.

sp.speaker: Goody.
sp.p: It is, is it—tell me then, what did you knock at that door for, but juſt now, when farmer Gregory was out?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: What for—why, to come in, to be ſure.

sp.speaker: Goody.
sp.p: But you found it locked; and, ſo rather than fail, you climbed up the wall, and jumped into my garden.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: That's another lie, Goody.

sp.speaker: Goody.
sp.p: We ſhall ſee—I can ſhew your father the fig-tree you broke in getting up.

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: What a wicked old woman you muſt be!

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: I tell you 'tis a pack of ſpight and malice—you broke the fig-tree yourſelf, I ſuppoſe, and now you have a mind to ſay I did it.

sp.speaker: Goody.
sp.p: And pray was it I too dropped this hat, (ſhewing the hat ſhe had before hid under her apron) which I found under the window?

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Oh! ho! I am no longer at a loſs to know how he came into the houſe.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Roſe!

sp.speaker: Roſe.
sp.p: Colin!—what ſhall we do?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.p: Get out of the houſe directly, you dog, and wait for me at the door.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: And do you ſo, to your chamber, this minute.

div.stage: (Colin goes ſlowly towards the door, regarding Roſe, who, as ſlowly, goes up-ſtairs.)

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Neighbour Higgins.

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.p: Neighbour Gregory.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Shall we try them any longer?

sp.speaker: Hig.
sp.p: They'll only make fools of us if we do.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Why, I believe you are in the right—come here, both of you, (They run towards each other) 'tis more than you deſerve, but we forgive you; and you, young dog, if you don't make her a good huſband—

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Ah! neighbour, there's no fear of that.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.p: Well, we have made good the old proverb at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Greg.
sp.l: Never talk of the care of a father,
Your children make happy much rather;
Nor ever the old crabbed Mentor
Love in at the window will enter,
If you ſhut it out at the door.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Never maids, ſhould the fit of love ſeize you,
Pine,
Whine,
But take, for a cure,
A kind conſtant youth that can pleaſe you.
In that will your happineſs center;
Not Cupid ſtill ſhunning,
For, ſpight of your cunning,
He in at the window will enter
If you ſhut him out at the door.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: This Cupid, ſly rogue, how he teazes!
All
Fall
Plump into his lure;
And he makes juſt whatever he pleaſes
Of thoſe in his trammels who venture;
From a clown, up to Pliny,
And he was no ninny,
Who ſaid at the window he'll enter,
If you ſhut him out at the door.
